ETYMOLOGY: From Old French 'capacité', from Latin 'capacitas' (abl. 'capacitatis') 'capability, power,' from 'capax' 'able to hold much,' from 'capere' 'to take, seize, hold.'

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The maximum amount that something can contain or produce.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 某物能容纳或生产的最大量。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The concert hall has a seating capacity of 2,000 people.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 这个音乐厅能容纳2000名观众。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The ability or power to do or understand something.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 做某事或理解某事的能力或力量。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: She has an amazing capacity for learning new languages.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 她学习新语言的能力很强。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: noun: a word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things (common noun), or to name a particular one of these (proper noun).
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: He acted in his capacity as a legal advisor.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 他以法律顾问的身份行事。
